stations.name: King's Cross St. Pancras
stations.trivia: Here you can find platforms for both the Eurostar and the Hogwarts Express.

stations.name: Liverpool Street
stations.trivia: Situated near a famously historic market, containing a herd of metal elephants.

stations.name: Oxford Circus
stations.trivia: Located at the intersection of one of the busiest shopping areas in Europe.

stations.name: Bond Street
stations.trivia: One of the world's most famous luxury shopping destinations, home to brands like Chanel, Louis Vuitton, Cartier, and Sotheby's auction house.

stations.name: Green Park
stations.trivia: Near a park that is unusual in that it has no permanent statues or buildings, just memorials.

stations.name: Leicester Square
stations.trivia: Alight here for cinemas and restaurants in the heart of London's West End theatre district.

stations.name: Piccadilly Circus
stations.trivia: Famous for its neon signs and the Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain with its statue of Anteros, often mistaken for Eros.

stations.name: Victoria
stations.trivia: Contrary to popular belief, this station was not named after a famous monarch.

stations.name: Waterloo
stations.trivia: The UK's busiest railway station by passenger usage.

stations.name: London Bridge
stations.trivia: The oldest railway terminus in London, opened in 1836.

stations.name: Bank
stations.trivia: This forms a complex with Monument station and serves the City of London.

stations.name: Westminster
stations.trivia: Alight here for Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament

stations.name: Embankment
stations.trivia: The only place on the Underground where you can still hear "Mind the Gap" announced by Oswald Laurence

stations.name: Charing Cross
stations.trivia: Traditionally considered the center of London for distance measurements.

stations.name: Tottenham Court Road
stations.trivia: Its name has nothing to do with a famous north London football club.

stations.name: Holborn
stations.trivia: Named after the nearby River Fleet, it serves the legal district of London.

stations.name: Euston
stations.trivia: The main London terminus for trains to the midlands, North West and Scotland.

stations.name: Earl's Court
stations.trivia: Once home to a famous exhibition center, it's a major interchange station serving West London.

stations.name: South Kensington
stations.trivia: Alight here for Museum Row.

stations.name: Notting Hill Gate
stations.trivia: Alight here for row of colourful houses and Portobello Road Market.

stations.name: Baker Street
stations.trivia: Alight here for the fictional home of Sherlock Holmes.

stations.name: Paddington
stations.trivia: A famous fictional bear is named after this station.

stations.name: Edgware Road
stations.trivia: Actually two physically separate stations amidst a large middle eastern community.

stations.name: Mile End
stations.trivia: Named after its location, it's one mile from the old City of London boundary at Aldgate.

stations.name: Finchley Road
stations.trivia: Serves the affluent areas of Swiss Cottage, St. John's Wood and Hampstead.

stations.name: Hammersmith
stations.trivia: Near a famous suspension bridge that was deemed too weak to support cars and pedestrianised.

stations.name: Stockwell
stations.trivia: Serves as an important interchange between North and South London.

stations.name: Balham
stations.trivia: Known as the 'Gateway to the South', this station serves both Underground and National Rail services in South London.

stations.name: Clapham Junction
stations.trivia: Britain's busiest railway station by train movements, handling over 2,000 trains per day with no Underground connection.

stations.name: Finsbury Park
stations.trivia: Serves a major music venue and one of North London's largest green spaces, popular for festivals and events.

stations.name: Barking
stations.trivia: This East London station was the terminus of the world's first electric tube railway when it opened in 1902.

stations.name: West Ham
stations.trivia: Forever Blowing Bubbles

stations.name: Moorgate
stations.trivia: Named after one of the ancient gates in the London Wall, this station serves the financial district.

stations.name: Acton Town
stations.trivia: An important junction title meaning Oak Town

stations.name: Ealing Common
stations.trivia: This area earned the nickname "The Queen of the Suburbs"

stations.name: Turnham Green
stations.trivia: A key interchange in Chiswick, serving both the District and Piccadilly lines with separate platforms.

stations.name: Barons Court
stations.trivia: Strategically located between Earl's Court and Hammersmith, serving the affluent West Kensington area.

stations.name: Farringdon
stations.trivia: A major Elizabeth line hub connecting to Thameslink services, serving the historic Smithfield Market area.

stations.name: Whitechapel
stations.trivia: Historic East London station famous for its connection to Jack the Ripper.

stations.name: Canary Wharf
stations.trivia: London's financial district skyscraper hub surrounded by waterways.

stations.name: Stratford
stations.trivia: Received a massive upgrade for the 2012 Olympic Games.

stations.name: Tower Hill
stations.trivia: A lesser known station, it serves the iconic Tower of London and Tower Bridge.

stations.name: Custom House
stations.trivia: Modern interchange station serving the ExCeL London exhibition center and London City Airport area.

stations.name: Highbury & Islington
stations.trivia: Named after the two main areas it serves.

stations.name: Canada Water
stations.trivia: One of two stations with another country in its name.

stations.name: Richmond
stations.trivia: Alight here if you want to go deer-spotting.

stations.name: Wimbledon
stations.trivia: Famous worldwide for its tennis championships

stations.name: Willesden Junction
stations.trivia: Originally known as "The Wilderness" due to its complex network of entrances and passages

stations.name: West Brompton
stations.trivia: It's got a compass direction in the name.

stations.name: Kensington Olympia
stations.trivia: Once home to a major exhibition center and events venue, now serves residential West London with connections to both Underground and Overground services.

stations.name: Shepherd's Bush
stations.trivia: A major West London transport hub serving the shopping and entertainment district, including the famous Westfield shopping center.

stations.name: Ealing Broadway
stations.trivia: The western terminus of the Central line and a major Elizabeth line station, serving as a key transport hub for West London and beyond.

stations.name: Shadwell
stations.trivia: Historic East London station in the heart of the former docklands.

stations.name: Warren Street
stations.trivia: Named after a developer who built houses in the area, it serves the bustling Fitzrovia district near the BBC Broadcasting House.
